channel.title: Ushome | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - all the latest US news, showbiz, science, sport and health stories from the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Barack Obama, Larry David and Robert Wolf play golf on Martha's Vineyard
item.description: President Obama spent Saturday playing golf with David and his usual opponent Cyrus Walker. Robert Wolf, the former head of UBS Investment Bank, rounded out the group in Massachusetts.

item.title: Atrocious handwriting on Illinois dad's parking permit gets his car towed and fined $218 after his 19th of June is mistaken for the 10th
item.description: Matthew Lesh from Chicago had his car towed and was left with a $218 fine after his bad handwriting on a permit displayed in his car window led to confusion.

item.title: Bernie Sanders forced to abandon rally after Black Lives Matter protesters storm stage and hold four-minute silence for Michael BrownÂ
item.description: Sanders was just starting to address several thousand people gathered shoulder to shoulder at Westlake Park , Seattle, when two women took over the microphone and wouldn't gibe it back.
item.media:description: Marissa Johnson, left, speaks as Mara Jacqueline Willaford holds her fist overhead and Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., stands nearby as the two women take over the microphone at a rally Saturday, Aug. 8, 2015, in downtown Seattle. The women, co-founders of the Seattle chapter of Black Lives Matter, took over the microphone and refused to relinquish it. Sanders eventually left the stage without speaking and instead waded into the crowd to greet supporters. (AP Photo/Elaine Thompson)

item.title: New Jersey man 'shoots his estranged wife 8 TIMES after she filed for divorce'
item.description: Marc Harrison, of Bayonne, faces charges of attempted murder, aggravated assault and several weapons offenses. The wounded woman was found by police in her home Thursday morning.

item.title: Aurora shooting victim's families WALKED OUT on hearing James Holmes sentence
item.description: James Holmes will spend the rest of his life in prison after at least one juror balked at the possibility of sentencing him to death for the massacre.

item.title: Social worker Lara Sobel who was' killed by woman who lost custody of daughter'
item.description: Lara Sobel, a veteran Department for Children and Families worker, was fatally shot on Friday afternoon outside of a state office building that houses the department, authorities said.

item.title: Michigan bookstore offering refunds for Harper Lee's Go Set A Watchman and calls controversial Mockingbird follow-up a 'first draft that was rightly rejected'
item.description: Brilliant Books, in Traverse City, said publisher HarperCollins misled readers to believe the book was a sequel or prequel for Harper Lee's beloved To Kill A Mockingbird.

item.title: Giant Florida alligator drags swimmer underwater and rips off her arm at the elbow - stopping only when nearby canoeist beats it with a paddle
item.description: The unnamed victim was enjoying the water in the Wekiva River, near Wekiva Springs, Florida, on Saturday afternoon when she was dragged under the water by the alligator.

item.title: Pennsylvania Attorney General Kathleen Kane arraigned for 'leaking secret details'
item.description: Pennsylvania Attorney General Kathleen Kane, 49, barely spoke as she was arraigned on charges including a felony count of perjury via closed-circuit television in suburban Philadelphia on Saturday.

item.title: Trump campaign in turmoil: War of words as tycoon 'firesâ key adviser who claims to have quit first, and Jeb Bush calls for apology over 'sexist' attack on Megyn Kelly
item.description: Trump's campaign said in a statement that the GOP presidential candidate fired his longtime friend, Roger Stone, last night. Not true, say allies of Stone - he quit.

item.title: Six Flags in New Orleans stands empty 10 years after Hurricane Katrina
item.description: Photographer Seph Lawless documented the decay of the Six Flags amusement park outside New Orleans following ten years of abandonment and failed redevelopment after Hurricane Katrina.

item.title: Gucci sisters Alessandra and Allegra's duplex listed for $45million
item.description: Alessandra and Allegra Gucci inherited the 9,500-square-foot penthouse after Maurizio Gucci was shot in 1995. The duplex, on the 50th and 51st floors, is currently rented out for $60,000 a month.

item.title: Auschwitz to a British auction house and how a family took on Nazi Art Masters
item.description: After his father's death, SIMON GOODMAN and his brother vowed to continue his battle to recover some of the artwork looted from their family by the Nazis.

item.title: Kelly Rutherford won't fly Helena and Hermes back to Daniel Giersch in Monaco
item.description: The actress was due to send Helena, six, and Hermes, eight, back to the French principality on Thursday, to be with her ex husband Daniel Giersch.

item.title: Formula One legend Juan Manuel Fangio exhumed to determine if men are his sons
item.description: The remains of Juan Manuel Fangio, who never married and was thought to be childless, were removed from a family crypt in his hometown of Balcarce, Argentina, on Friday.

item.title: Jennifer Garner and Ben Affleck wear wedding bands during Atlanta family outing
item.description: It has been two months since they revealed plans to divorce, yet Jennifer Garner and Ben Affleck are said to continue sporting their wedding rings for the well-being of their three children.
item.media:description: 140991, Ben Affleck and Jennifer Garner reunite as they step out in Atlanta with children Seraphina and Samuel - both wearing their wedding rings! Affleck and Garner recently announced they would be divorcing after 10 years of marriage, shortly after allegations surfaced that Affleck was having an affair with the family's 28 year-old nanny, Christine Ouzounian. Affleck was spotted arriving in Atlanta yesterday, where Garner has been filming 'Miracles from Heaven.' The family were seen entering a local mall. Atlanta, Georgia - Saturday August 8, 2015. Photograph: Â© RGK, PacificCoastNews. Los Angeles Office: +1 310.822.0419 sales@pacificcoastnews.com FEE MUST BE AGREED PRIOR TO USAGE

item.title: Burning Man won't have Bureau of Land Management officials and police in luxury
item.description: The US Bureau of Land Management rescinded its request for VIP housing for law enforcement and officials from Washington, DC, at the event. The event in Nevada's Black Rock Desert starts August 30.

item.title: The Queen's Â£40k luxury loft for the royal racing pigeons on Sandringham estate
item.description: The Queen is having to splash out on a luxury new home for her royal pigeons after their loft on the Sandringham estate has started to subside and has rotting timbers and poor flooring.

item.title: 1 of Cecil the lion's cubs killed by a rival after dentist Walter Palmer shot him
item.description: The much-loved lion was killed by American dentist Walter Palmer in Zimbabwe last month - sparking outrage around the world.

item.title: Incredible pictures show South African Cape ground squirrels
item.description: These two squirrels were photographed in the grips of what looks like the sensual South American dance. They were pictured in their natural habitat in South Africa's Kgalagadi Transfrontier Park.

item.title: Mike Brown's father leads a Ferguson march through to mark son's death
item.description: Mike Brown Sr. said he is 'still hurting' almost a year to the day since his son was shot dead by then-police officer Darren Wilson in Ferguson, ahead of a weekend of protests around the city.
item.media:description: Michael Brown Sr. speaks through a megaphone as he takes part in a parade in honor of his son, Michael Brown, Saturday, Aug. 8, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo. Sunday will mark one year since Michael Brown was shot and killed by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson. (AP Photo/Jeff Roberson)

item.title: Prince Harry joins war on poachers at Crocodile River in Kruger Park
item.description: Prince Harry is at the front line of a bloody war against rhino poachers, joining heavily armed forces battling gangs of criminals wielding rifles and machetes.

item.title: Steven Spielberg is selling Â£120m, 282ft mega yacht because it is 'too small'
item.description: Forty years after Roy Scheider exclaimed, âWeâre gonna need a bigger boatâ in Jaws â it seems the filmâs director Steven Spielberg has taken the sentiment very firmly to heart.

item.title: Richard Branson and how his mother Eve Branson brought him up
item.description: Eve Branson tells AMY OLIVER about raising her 'absolutely impossible' son and reveals the truth about being 'saved' by Kate Winslet from a raging inferno on Necker Island in 2011.

item.title: Eric Clapton's rift with daughter Ruth who tweeted that he dressed up as Kermit
item.description: The guitarist has become secretly estranged from his daughter Ruth in a bitter rift that threatens to tear the family apart, with sources revealing the cause of the row as her tweets.

item.title: Police and MI5 race to foil IED attack on the Queen at World War II anniversary
item.description: The Mail on Sunday can reveal that police and MI5 are involved in a frantic race against time to thwart the assassination plot in London, which is being orchestrated from Syria by Islamic State commanders.

item.title: Google likely to pick Presidential candidates whose names come on top of search
item.description: Undecided voters were 12 per cent more likely to pick candidates whose name appeared at the top of a search, a U.S. study showed, meaning the site has likely already helped to sway elections.
item.media:description:
The Google search engine webpage being reflected in an eye.
The Google search engine webpage being reflected in an eye. (Photo by: Newscast/UIG via Getty Images)

item.title: Donald Trump was talking about Fox host Megyn Kelly's NOSE at GOP conference
item.description: In an interview with CNN on Friday, Donald Trump appearedÂ to imply that Kelly 'unfairly' grilled him on his history of insulting women during a televised debateÂ because she was menstruating.

item.title: Nagasaki light lanterns for Hiroshima where the US planes dropped atom bomb
item.description: Thousands gathered to observe a touching vigil (pictured) as an image of the blast's mushroom cloud was projected onto the Urakami Cathedral which was destroyed by the bomb 70 years ago.

item.title: Corrections officer Michael O'Neill had white supremacist materials in parent's garage
item.description: Michael O'Neill, 45, had Nazi symbols, Confederate flag memorabilia and Ku Klux Klan posters hanging up when he blew off his leg with an explosive in a garage inÂ Wheatland, New York, last month.

item.title: Apple to unveil its new iPhone and iPad on September 9
item.description: Sources in the know claim Apple is planning an event for the week of September 7, with September 9 being the most likely date for its annual autumn media event.

item.title: Delta Airlines pilots make emergency landing after hail storm cracked windshield
item.description: The Delta Airlines flight from Boston to Salt Lake City had to land in Denver on Friday evening after a storm wrecked the front of the plane - including its GPS navigation system.

item.title: Humans evolved large brains because our ancestors ate POTATOES
item.description: Researchers at the Autonomous University of Barcelona say starches would have been readily available to ancestral human populations in the form of potatoes, nuts and seeds.

item.title: Predators have vertical slits for pupils, while prey have 'letterbox' shaped holes
item.description: Scientists at the University of California at Berkeley studied the eyes of 214 land species to deduce that predators have differently shaped eyes to prey.

item.title: Joe Biden will spend week-long retreat deciding whether to run for President
item.description: Vice President Joe Biden and his wife are retreating from Washington for a week in South Carolina with little on their schedule but a momentous decision to make: whether he should run for president.
item.media:description: FILE - In this July 21, 2015, file photo, Vice President Joe Biden speaks during a roundtable discussion at the Advanced Manufacturing Center at Community College of Denver. Biden and his wife are retreating from Washington for a week in South Carolina with little on their schedule but a momentous decision to make: whether he should run for president. (AP Photo/Brennan Linsley, File)

item.title: American soldier dies in attack on NATO base in Afghanistan
item.description: The soldier was killed along with eight local contractors at Camp Integrity in Kabul - just one of three attacks on the city by insurgents in less than 24 hours. More than 355 civilians were injured.

item.title: David and Ornella Steiner who died in New Mexico desert likely saved son giving him their water
item.description: David Steiner, 42, and his wife, Ornella Steiner, 51Â died during an afternoon hike across the searing New Mexico desert. They were tourists from the small town of Bourgogne, France.

item.title: Eminem sparks outrage with disturbing rap that describes raping women on soundtrack for Straight Outta Compton
item.description: The 42-year-old father-of-three screams, 'I even make the b****es I rape c*m,' in a rap solo on Dr Dre's song Medicine Man. The line has been met with a storm of criticism.

item.title: Michael Moore is selling his Michigan Torch Lake house after Kathleen Glynn divorce
item.description: Filmmaker Michael Mooreâs former vacation home in the Traverse City area is up for sale. The home on Torch Lake in northern Michigan is on the market for $5.2 million.

item.title: New Jersey mother of bisexual teens responds to anti-gay graffiti by painting it rainbowÂ
item.description: Erin Kennedy DeLong of Villas, New Jersey, and her husband Joe, turned the door into a symbol of pride for their daughters after a vandal scrawled 'I'm gay' across it in black paint.

item.title: Ex-Soviet tank commander Irek Hamidullin found guilty of Taliban terror charges in USA
item.description: A former Soviet army officer accused of being a Taliban fighter has been found guilty of terrorism charges by a federal jury in Richmond, Virginia, a court official said yesterday.

item.title: NYC fired dead worker Geoffrey Toliver because he missed 18 months of work
item.description: Social services worker Geoffrey Toliver, 65, died in December - 13 months after stopping work due to his illness. The Human Resources Administration said it tried to reach him for a year.

item.title: Moment morbidly obese sisters walk unaided for the first time after weight loss
item.description: Yogita Rameshbhai Nandwana (in red), five, weighed 5st 5lbs and sister Anisha (wearing green), three , 7st 8lbs, but the sisters from India have both lost 13 pounds thanks to a restricted diet.
item.media:credit: IMAGE SUPPLIED BY COVER ASIA PRESS

item.title: Incredible aerial pictures of the worlds greatest cities and sights
item.description: The images were taken by a group of Russian photographers, who travel the world snapping its most wondrous sights from helicopters, planes, hot air balloons and radio-controlled devices.

item.title: Sunbathers watch as rubber dinghy full of migrants arrive in Greece
item.description: Stretched on their beach towels and enjoying the blazing sunshine, the tourists seem unfazed by the dark green dingy, crammed full with people as it slowly approached the shore of Kos, Greece

item.title: Five women beaten to death in rural India accused of being witches
item.description: GRAPHIC CONTENT WARNING: The attackers used sticks, iron rods and knives in Kinjia village, near the Jharkhand state capital Ranchi. The women's bodies were wrapped in plastic bags (pictured).

item.title: Over 100 former Saddam Hussein-era officers make up ISIS leadership
item.description: Once part of one of the most brutal dictator's army in the Middle East, over 100 former members of Saddam Hussein's military and intelligence officers are now part of ISIS in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Attorneys say prosecutors hid evidence in Freddie Gray case
item.description: Lawyers for the six Baltimore officers charged with various counts for the death of Gray, 25, claim he was involved in 'crash-for-cash' schemes, including one that required medical attention.

item.title: Romantic floating restaurant opens in China's Zhejiang Province
item.description: For anyone in search of a unique dining experience, look no further. The romantic restaurant is fashioned out of a wooden floating dock, and looks to only accommodate parties of two.

item.title: Verizon ditches two-year contracts in favor of month-by-month billing for cellphones...but will it end up costing more?
item.description: The changes to both its device data plans and its smartphone purchase options go into effect on August 13 and Verizon hopes that the move will simplify things.

item.title: MoD scientists tested anthrax and the PLAGUE on soldiers and public
item.description: Over the course of half a century, the Ministry of Defence carried out a series of shocking experiments on unwitting volunteers. A new book exposes the grim reality of the human 'guinea pigs'.

item.title: Billionaire Dougherty Novella family 'shocked' at son who 'killed partner in sex game'
item.description: The billionaire Dougherty Novella family, one of Guatemala's richest clans, told Mail Online they are 'shocked' that relative Diego Dougherty, 41, has been accused of killing girlfriend Gabriela Kabrins.

item.title: Texas officer Brad Miller in fatally shoots unarmed Christian Taylor in Arlington
item.description: Christian Taylor was killed by Officer Brad Miller at the Classic Buick GMC dealership in Arlington, Texas early Friday morning. Police said they were responding to a burglary in progress.

item.title: Japanese Nagasaki bomb survivor reveals scars 70 years later
item.description: Pensioner Sumitery Taniguchi, now 86, was just 16 at the time of the second atomic attack on Japan, over Nagasaki. He spent 21 months lying on his stomach as his horrifying injuries healed.

item.title: Women make better magicians than men, claims president of the Magic Circle
item.description: Scott Penrose says that women are better suited to some tricks, and TV magician Katherine Mills, pictured, joked she may even hire a male assistant and 'dress him in Spandex'.

item.title: Parisians face baguette shortage after change to French law
item.description: For first time since the French Revolution bakers in the capital, like this one in Montmartre, can close when they want to after a 1790 law was scrapped as part of a government drive to cut red tape.

item.title: Typhoon Soudelor hits Taiwan, killing six, as it approaches mainland China
item.description: The eye of the storm passed over the island nation at around midday, injuring 101 and cancelling all domestic flights. The storm is approaching Zhejiang in China (pictured).

item.title: Telling a person they're fat makes them even fatter
item.description: Psychologists found that believing you are overweight is counter productive â highlighting a problem for doctors trying to combat the obesity epidemic.

item.title: Bangladeshi blogger Niloy Chatterjee hacked to death by Islamists in Dhaka
item.description: WARNING: GRAPHIC CONTENT. Suspected Islamists armed with machetes hacked a blogger to death in his home in Bangladesh today. Niloy Chatterjee used his blog to promote secularism

item.title: Django Unchained actress Daniele Watts ordered to rewrite apology letter to LAPD
item.description: Daniele Watts' first note merely apologized to the police officer for disturbing 'your carefree coffee break' and thanked him for giving her the opportunity to shine a light on racial profiling.

item.title: Transgender convicted murderer Michelle-Lael Norsworthy to be RELEASED from prison after 28 years
item.description: The settlement agreement was reached Friday even as the inmate whose court victory had paved the way for such taxpayer-paid surgery learned she will not get it but be released from prison instead.

item.title: Speech clinics help transgender patients find their voices
item.description: The University of Connecticut's Speech and Hearing Clinic is one of a growing number of clinics with programs.

item.title: Fireman the Chihuahua puppy finds new home with young burn victim girlÂ
item.description: The six-month-old puppy, Fireman, who also responds to Buddy, was adopted by 12-year-old Chloe Levenson last week, who also suffered from burns following an incident as baby.

item.title: Santeria priest 'used HEALING ritual as cover to sexually abuse on girl, 16'
item.description: Pablo Pinto Mata, a 46-year-old cleric of the Santeria religion, is accused of the sex attack against the minor, in Montebello, California, where police say he forced her to undress for him.

item.title: Philadelphia service dog Yolanda calls 911 during fire and saves blind owner's life
item.description: A golden retriever namedÂ Yolanda warned authorities about the house fire on Thursday morning at her home in the Holmesburg section of Philadelphia. She called on a special phone and firefighters responded.

item.title: Science Advances reveals our eye shape helped turn humans into hunters
item.description: A study found humans became successful hunters (file photo) because our eyes have circular pupils, as opposed to the elongated horizontal ones of plant-eating animals such as sheep.

item.title: Chinese hackers target American Airlines and travel reservation company Sabre
item.description: Sabre Corp, a Texas-based company that provides technology used for airline and hotel reservations, confirmed hack but isn't sure if any data was stolen.

item.title: Slicing a bagel along the 'Mobius Strip' is best way to add more filling
item.description: A video shows how to cut a bagel into a MÃ¶bius strip, which a famous mathematical structure that only has one side, providing more surface area to spread cream cheese.

item.title: Peeps' autumn-inspired marshmallow candies put to the testÂ
item.description: Peeps is debuting pumpkin spice, candy corn, and caramel apple flavors this September - just in time for fall. The beloved treats will be sold exclusively at Target and the brand's online store.

item.title: Mars salt flats could be last place water survived on the red planet
item.description: Researchers have discovered evidence of an ancient lake that likely represents some of the last potentially habitable surface water ever to exist on the Red Planet.
item.media:description:
Salt flat indicates some of the last vestiges of surface water on Mars, CU-Boulder study finds -
Mars turned cold and dry long ago, but researchers at the University of Colorado Boulder have discovered evidence of an ancient lake that likely represents some of the last potentially habitable surface water ever to exist on the Red Planet.
The study, published Thursday in the journal Geology, examined an 18-square-mile chloride salt deposit (roughly the size of the city of Boulder) in the planet?s Meridiani region near the Mars Opportunity rover?s landing site. As seen on Earth in locations such as Utah?s Bonneville Salt Flats, large-scale salt deposits are considered to be evidence of evaporated bodies of water.
Digital terrain mapping and mineralogical analysis of the features surrounding the deposit indicate that this one-time lakebed is no older than 3.6 billion years old, well after the time period when Mars is thought to have been warm enough to sustain large amounts of surface

item.title: Couple's 1st dance begins to Justin Timberlake before busting out 6-minute routine
item.description: Hollie and Dave Smith shunned the traditional slow, romantic first dance in favour of an all-singing, all-dancing routine, which the British couple choreographed for their special day.

item.title: Courtney Jording and mother Karen 'shot up heroin in car with baby girl in back seat'
item.description: Courtney Jording, 23, was allegedly spotted injecting her mother, 43-year-old Karen Gillespie, with the Schedule I drug as they sat inside a car at a Sheetz gas station in Greensburg, Pennsylvania.

item.title: weatherView shows Typhoon Soudelor hitting land via an interactive map
item.description: Named weatherView, the map allows you to switch on various layers showing the planetâs temperature, precipitation, moisture and pressure, as well as see the world's air currents in detail.

item.title: Texan police chief is tasered by junior officer after losing Facebook bet
item.description: Derek Dyson of Danbury Police Department, Texas, had claimed his force couldn't get 1,600 Facbook likes as the town only had 1,600 residents. But as word of the bet spread, the target was reached.

item.title: Florida brothers Elias and D.C. Goutoufas hear each other for the first time
item.description: Elias and D.C. Goutoufas, who are from Tampa, Florida, have been deaf all their lives due to a congenital defect. The moment they heard each other for the first time was captured on video.

item.title: Tolkien estate lawyers threaten Suffolk couple over hobbit hole campsite advertÂ
item.description: Jan and Ed Lengyel, both 53, have been threatened with legal action by the Tolkien Estate over plans to build their luxury 'poddit hole' for Lord of the Rings fans at their Suffolk campsite.

item.title: Couple of 68 years reunited while both are patients in Piedmont Fayette Hospital
item.description: A hospital worker's actions brought a 96-year-old man to tears after she helped to reunite him with his beloved wife of 68 years. The couple was put in separate rooms at Piedmont Fayette Hospital.

item.title: Teen couple Dylan and Lexie survive lightning strike by holding hands
item.description: A doctor told Dylan and Lexie of Claremont, California that holding hands helped diffuse the electrical current that hit them.

item.title: 2 people get long jail sentences for insulting Thai monarchy on Facebook
item.description: A Thai man named Pongsak Sriboonpeng and a mother-of-two both had their prison terms halved for pleading guilty to insulting the country's monarch (King Bhumibol pictured)

item.title: SkyWest plane bursts into FLAMES at Nashville International Airport
item.description: The Delta-operated regional jet, carrying dozens of passengers, caught fire after the pilot turned on its engine while departing Nashville International Airport in Tennessee on Friday.

item.title: Boars WASH their food before eating it at Basel Zoo, Switzerland
item.description: When presented with grubby apples, a group of boars at Basel Zoo, Switzerland carry the treats to a river using their snouts and carefully wash them in the water.

item.title: Will we soon spot Little Green PLANTS in space? Light from our closest star Alpha Centauri could reveal signs of alien life on its planets
item.description: Astronomers have found that photosynthetic pigments in plants, algae and bacteria reflect light in distinctive ways, which may make it possible to spot life on planets orbiting distant stars.

item.title: Mackeral attacks surfer who suffers broken cheek and dislocated jaw
item.description: A 27-year-old surfer fell from his board off the coast of Sao Vicente, Brazil, and suffered severe facial injuries. Surgeons removed the jaw of a white snake mackerel (pictured) from his nasal cavity.

item.title: Super typhoon Soudelor to hit Taiwan and China with wind speeds of 100mph
item.description: Full force of Typhoon Soudelor is expected to hit Taiwan August 7 and 8. South eastern coast of China will also be affected by the tropical storm. 2,000 people have been evacuated and two died.

item.title: John Dee Weter 'beat girlfriend to death with a machete in front of her 2 kids'
item.description: John Dee Weter Jr, 31, was arrested in Montgomery County, Texas Thursday night after allegedly murdering his 33-year-old girlfriend, Michelle Becker.

item.title: Is this a witch's skeleton? 1.4k-year-old bones unearthed at Rollright Stones
item.description: The remains were discovered near the Rollright Stones in Warwickshire, which legend has it were created when a witch turned a king and his knights to stone.

item.title: Was life on Earth jump-started by underwater volcanoes?
item.description: Scientists from Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California have managed to power a light bulb using geothermal vents built in the lab that simulate conditions on the ocean floor when life first arose.

item.title: Ohio woman dies from Legionnaires' disease after 10th person passes away in NY
item.description: Elaine Stacer, 53, died at University Hospital in Cleveland yesterday morning from Legionnaires' disease as investigators try to work out how and where she was infected.
item.media:description:
PHOTO: Elaine Stacer (left)
A woman died in Cleveland from Legionnaires? disease on Thursday, health officials confirmed to newsnet5.com.
Our app users learned about this story first. Download our newsnet5 app here to stay up to date on breaking news.
Elaine Stacer, 53, of Brunswick, died Thursday morning at University Hospital, according to a spokesperson at the hospital and Cuyahoga County health officials.
Stacer was admitted to a different hospital on July 24. University Hospital said Stacer was very ill when she was brought to their hospital.
Family members told newsnet5.com Stacer was healthy prior to the infection.
Stacer also suffered a stroke after being diagnosed with Legionnaires? disease, University Hospital said.
Officials are not sure how Stacer contracted the disease yet.
NewsChannel5 Investigator Sarah Buduson spoke with a Cuyahoga County health official who said they will be working with health officials in Medina County to investigate Stacer's death.
The

item.title: Botswana elephants enjoy drinking from a toilet rather than their water hole
item.description: Sneaking out for a quick call of nature, one camper got the surprise of her life when she came across an elephant drinking out of one of the campsite lavatories in Botswana.

item.title: Hundreds of balloons take off at start of Balloon Fiesta in Bristol
item.description: The 37th International Balloon Fiesta launched in Bristol with half a million visitors expected. Among the 103 balloons in the sky today was one of the largest Tibetan flags, which caused a stir ahead.
